title: AB 933
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The Legislature enacted the 24/7 Sobriety program in California to qualify for FAST Act grant funding and NHTSA funding. Section 23582.5 of the Vehicle Code allows the court to order individuals convicted of DUI offenses to participate in a 24/7 Sobriety program as a condition of probation, parole, or sentence if certain criteria are met. The court may require a person arrested for DUI to enroll in a 24/7 Sobriety program as a condition of release on bond if certain criteria are met. A person with a suspended or revoked driving privilege can enroll in a 24/7 Sobriety program to obtain a restricted driving privilege, if deemed appropriate and within 10 years of a DUI conviction. Participation in the program may be required for a minimum of one year. A "24/7 Sobriety program" requires participants to abstain from alcohol or drugs, undergo frequent testing, and face immediate sanctions for violations. The program must be evidence-based, meeting specific criteria for effectiveness. The 24/7 Sobriety program evaluation is peer-reviewed and endorsed by a federal agency or respected research organization. Participants may also be required to join other DUI programs, with testing locations prioritizing timely sanctions for violations. Program costs are based on the individual's ability to pay. The court may impose a program up to 180 days if the defendant tests positive for alcohol or drugs. The Office of Traffic Safety must include provisions for the 24/7 Sobriety program in its highway safety plan. The department will collect data on participant demographics, case history, testing information, and fees. Section 1808 of the Vehicle Code allows public inspection of department records related to vehicle registration, driver's license applications, convictions, and accident reports during office hours. Accident reports are available to law enforcement agencies and courts. The department in Sacramento provides abstracts of convictions and accident reports based on the date of occurrence: ten years for certain violations, seven years for violations with two points, and three years for accidents and other violations. The department in Sacramento provides abstracts of convictions and accident reports based on the date of occurrence: ten years for certain violations, seven years for violations with two points, and three years for accidents and all other violations. The department discloses suspensions and revocations of driving privileges for three years following termination of the action or reinstatement, except for specific cases where disclosure is limited to the actual suspension period. Judicially set aside or stayed suspensions or revocations are not disclosed. The department in Sacramento discloses convictions of specific offenses for 10 years to courts and law enforcement agencies for penalty enforcement, in compliance with the Driver's Privacy Protection Act. The department in Sacramento discloses convictions of specific offenses for penalty enforcement to courts and law enforcement agencies. Consent for the use of a driver's license number by insurance agents or employers is presumed if provided for insurance coverage or employment eligibility. The insurance agent or broker can transmit motor vehicle records for specific purposes and is not responsible for how the recipient handles the records. Before transmitting records to an insurer without a written agreement, the broker or agent must obtain an agreement ensuring compliance with state and federal laws on fair credit reporting and privacy.
